body_html: With make_template there won't be multiple copies of the graph. Tensorboard nicely shows that the two queues (one for training data, the other for validation data) share one graph with the weights (True, you need to have two different smaller pieces of loss expressions that are associated with the queue and are placed on top of the one graph that has the trainable parameters). Deciding which queue is used is done on the outer training iteration loop, no tf.cond or any other expression-based logic necessary, you just sess.run the respective loss expression and the underlying queue is polled.

body: With `make_template` there won't be multiple copies of the graph. Tensorboard nicely shows that the two queues (one for training data, the other for validation data) share one graph with the weights (True, you need to have two different smaller pieces of loss expressions that are associated with the queue and are placed on top of the one graph that has the trainable parameters). Deciding which queue is used is done on the outer training iteration loop, no tf.cond or any other expression-based logic necessary, you just sess.run the respective loss expression and the underlying queue is polled.
